comment._content: I found an advert in the Irish Times from Wednesday, 6 August 1879 that makes the state of the house in this photograph all the more baffling. Ballyellis House is described as a "Most Desirable Gentlemanly Residence" and "in good order"!!

comment._content: Only one house listed in Ballyellis in the 1901 census.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Your ruins don't look big enough to be the house in the picture and the footprint on the OSI doesn't match the picture either, though they do match the ruins.

comment.author: 8468254@N02

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Here it is from the main road: maps.google.ie/?ll=52.713211,-6.457686&spn=0.007825,0...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Glad you have an occasional D'oh! moment too! [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] I'm been zooming up and down that road, and had settled on your ruin too, but it doesn't look right to me. Have a look at the side of the house in the photo above. It had double gables with a valley in the roof. The ruin doesn't really look like that. Plus if you stroll down the road and have a look at the "doors" and "windows" in the front of the ruin. They don't look at all the same. 2 Archways look as if this was an agricultural building? And the roof walls show it as a one storey structure...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: Isn't that the parochial house on Craggy Island? Father Ted needs to do some DIY!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Could the Doyles have built a new house and abandoned this one? I see a planning application from 2006: 20062122 WEXFORD AREA 13-Jun-2006 04-Aug-2006 REFUSED Applicant: MICHAEL DOYLE Ballyellis House, Gorey, Co Wexford Location: HARPOONSTOWN, BRIDGETOWN Proposal: ERECTION OF A FULLY SERVICED DWELLING HOUSE

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] The original house shown is gone. At the left of the photo, you can see buildings extending back from the house, and those are the ruins which are still there. They were barns or stables, from the doorways, and could have been in use after the house was abandoned.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Yet the structure of the first house picked up by the Lemur is similar to the original image with the double roof?  I have to admit that the condition of the house in the original does not bode well for its survival and it is unlikely to have been restored at that time period in Ireland.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] The replete out-offices from our auctioneer's advert in effect.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
On Google Maps, the Lemur's house is called Ballyellis House. That is why the OS search found it.

I think the Doyles built a new house, moved themselves and the house name.

But when?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
But what's still bothering me is... The auctioneer, in August 1879, described our house above as being "in good order". This photo could only have been taken between 1865 and 1914, and with such a high Lawrence negative number, I'd imagine it was well after 1879.

Was the auctioneer being very economical with the truth? I think that has been known to happen? Or what had happened in a decade or so after 1879 for this "Most Desirable Gentlemanly Residence" to fall into such decrepitude?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The Doyles were in Ballyellis in 1835, so they didn't buy the property at that auction. If the house did not sell and was abandoned in 1879, it could easily look decrepit by 1910, 30 years later.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: The buildings on the back right don't seem to be on the map either, unless they're down at the crossroads. They look a bit near for that.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: I don't see any other big houses around Carnew on the OSI that look like they match it but I'm suspicious. The 25" would generally inlcude that porch in the ground outline, but it's not there, and it has the back of the house set in a bit, which it isn't in the picture. It doesn't seem to be Ballyellis in Cork either - the chimneys are in the wrong place. landedestates.nuigalway.ie/LandedEstates/img/orig/1553.jpg

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] I'm 100% happy it's Ballyellis at Carnew (or close by). See these! And another controversy - is this part of Carnew in Wexford or Wicklow?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] The step in the outhouses matches the ruins and the OS Map, and the topography looks right. I'd agree with [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/] that this is the same house.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I am very confident that this is the house marked Ballyellis house on the OS 6 and 25" maps, and the ruin in streetview.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] There is also an undigitised and mislabelled photo of Ballykellis, Carnew

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Thanks Eagle Eye! I've amended the title to Ballyellis on our library management system, so when the database next updates it'll be correct.

Back to Wicklow versus Wexford though. I had a look on Google Maps and it seems that Carnew itself is in Wicklow, but that Ballyellis is just over the border in Wexford. Anyone confirm please?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: There is a cross very nearby in streetview. I can't read any inscriptions, but given all the 1798 references I've come across, I would guess it's commemorating the Battle of Ballyellis in 1798.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] The OS maps confirm that the border is West of here at Ballyellis crossroads, and that we are on the Wexford side here.

comment.author: 30369211@N00

comment.author: 7922758@N06
comment._content: Bally Ellis House, Near Gorey, Co. Wexford. A double gable ended 2 storey early 18th ce house. 5 bay front with small single storey Doric portico with paired columns, probably a later addition. Derelict by the end of the 19th C - now demolished.

comment.author: 7922758@N06
comment._content: The Jervis-White-Jervis Baronetcy, of Bally Ellis in the County of Waterford, was a title in the Baronetage of Ireland. It was created on 6 December 1797 for John Jervis-White-Jervis. The title became extinct on the death of the fifth Baronet in 1947.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/archiseek] Thank you, Paul! So basically (with no disrepect to any surviving relatives of auctioneer and valuer, Daniel Johnson) the auctioneer was telling porkies when he said the house was "in good order" at the start of August 1879...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: So, not the family home of the Doyles, but the seat of the Jervis-White-Jervis'seses, baronets!

comment.author: 7922758@N06

comment.author: 7922758@N06
comment._content: Pedigree of White Jervis, Barts., of Ballyellis, Co. Wexford with copy of Patent of Baronetcy, c.1720 -- 1797. is in Library Towers sources.nli.ie/Record/MS_UR_040937
